title: Master Solvers' Club
excerpt: Monthly bidding problems with expert panel solutions and scoring.

Yes, they do have plenty of room.

GEORGE CARAVELLI: "Four diamonds. I'll bid as far as I'm willing to go, if East is declarer; I'm on lead; if West declares a slam, I can double (and hope)."

HENRY BETHE: "Four diamonds. Looks about right on loser count."

Maybe at a worse vulnerability.

Many of the three-diamond bidders are also planning to bid again.

JOHN LOWENTHAL: "Three diamonds. Keep it low. Maybe I'll get a chance to bid three notrump, which will depict my hold-ing fairly well. I have bad experiences preempting with hands such as this. (Of course, I've also had bad experiences when my opponents preempted.)"

You'd have a really hard time convincing him that you have such a strong hand. But why should we give up on seven, especially to reach opposite many fitting hands easy to reach opposite your little point in bidding two diamonds? As to passing three no-trump, anything we'd print would be censored by the editor, so we had best say nothing at all.

**ARTHUR ROBINSON**: "c. Four clubs. I assume that 100% forcing."

Yes, we assume that. Too bad it has nothing to do with your hand. Is this some new system where new suits in competition show voids?

Chip MARTEL: "a. Three hearts, then four hearts. Should show the ace (with a singleton, I'd probably bid four hearts directly; slam prospects are too good to bid four spades."

Let's get back to reality and see if we should start with three hearts or three spades. The three-spade bidders are trying to save space, while the three-heart bidders are trying to give a better picture.

DAVID BERKOWITZ: "b. Three spades, then RKB Clubs; "Four diamonds." Pass all bids except to lead (if west bid seven, count their hand.

MARSHALL MILES: "Three diamonds. In my youth, I would have bid two spades, but I don't need description tactics (or a bid for two spades).

Yes, we agree. Pass has much more flexibility than that lovely two-ender, more chance of success than that lovely two-world of success than that lovely twoender.

IRA RUBIN: "Four diamonds. Only four diamonds as a bad split may wreak havoc upon East. Besides, how will partner ever lead opposite your five-diamond bid? Also clubs works with this type of hand, where I expect to be on lead (if we de-fend), and they don't tackle to end in [tackle]."

**SEPTEMBER HONOR ROLL**

Don Stack, of Overland Park, KS, led October with a score of 790. Jeff Gressmen followed with 770.

Because of adjustments in Club proces-dures (see Editorial), averages of sam-pled solvers are no longer compiled.

These scores were added on the Sep-tember problems: (D) pass, then one notrump; 40; pass, then two notrump, 30; (E) two spades, 70.

Eddie Kantar entered a correction to one of his remarks: He suggests that one heart — (two spades) — three clubs — (pass) — four diamonds be used to ask for key cards with clubs agreed; however, over advancer's three spades, as in September problem G, four diamonds should show diamonds.

Phil King and John can hope for a dia-mond lead, but a simulation surely would show that it's not a heart, it course not. Bridge is a game where you must be focused; not knowing whose lead it is should cause a loss, just as any other lapse in concentration. That's why we have rules, Michael; you can be sure that if your table was playing in a world championship, with Edgar, hav-ing descended from above (we expect), as your captain, he would be mighty disappointed at your attitude.

EDDIE KANTAR: "d.I have problems like this."

Do you mean problems like H, or problems like all eight of these? Not to worry, Eddie, your score of 640 is not a bad way to start the new year.

**TEST YOUR PLAY SOLUTIONS**

Suppose you play trumps early; tak-ing two rounds and winning the open-ing lead. If spades turn out to be four-one, you are in trouble. If you switch to hearts, the defender with four trumps may be able to ruff in and lead a trump, leaving you a trick short. Alternatively, if you take two club ruffs after the sec-ond trump you will still face a di-lemma: when you lead a fourth round of trumps, the long-trump defender may have another club, should you fin-stead try hearts, the third round may be ruffed, cutting you off from the pitch for your diamond loser.
